div1.p: United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for Gwoo Shee Ah Look. } No. 2647 Filed April , 1914.
Wilbur & Spencer of Portland, Ore., A. L. Clark, or Portland Ore., Jesse A. Frye, of Seattle, Wash., For Petitioner.
Clay Allen, U.S. District Attorney, Geo. F. Fishburne, Assistant District Atty. For Respondent.
Neterer, District Judge.

A writ of habeas corpus was issued in this case on the 13th day of January, 1914, upon the application of the petitioner, to which return has been made. The return shows that on the 5th day of November, 1913, a warrant for arrest of Gwoo Shee Ah Look was issued, and she was taken into custody. It would appear that a general raid was made on November 4th, 1913, of the city of Portland by the police officers of the city, and the petitioner together with some other women were arrested. A report was made to the immigration commissioner of the arrest of the petitioner, and she was taken into custody under the warrant above stated and given a hearing. On the same day the commissioner was advised by Mr. Clark, representing the firm of Wilbur & Spencer, laywers, that they had been retained on behalf of Gwoo Shee Ah Look, and desired to consult with her. This request was denied, as were also the subsquent requests which were made practically every day until after the 17th day of November when all of the testimony against the petitioner had been taken, except that on November 10th a conference was permitted. On the 17th the attorney for the petitioner was told over the phone to prepare to present such evidence as he desired by way of affidavits and the same would be forwarded with the report to the secretary of labor. At the close of the petitioner's examination on November 10th, she was advised:

"Q. Do you desire to designate any attorney or representative to appear for you at this hearing. A. I wish to notify Wong On, Manager of the Kwong Man Yun Comapny in this city. Q. Do you know him personally. A. My husband knows him, I do not know him."
This party was not advised, nor was counsel for petitioner permitted to be persent at this hearing. The petitioner does not understand nor speak English.

The record discloses that the order of deportation was based upon the testimony of two policemen who made the raid, which testimony shows that they had the petitioner under surveillance for some two or three weeks, and they had watched the room in which t she was arrested in this building and had seen men go in and out of the room; that on the night of the arrest about 4 o'clock in the morning they went to the door and knocked and the woman opened the door, and that she and a man were in bed together. The petitioner furnishes affidavits from Walter Bartholomew, a white man and a paper hanger, who papered the rooms in which the petitioner was arrested about the 1st of November, and he swears positively that the petitioner did not move into those rooms prior to November 1st. Sue Key Line and his wife swear positively that the petitioner lived at their home from the 18th of October to November 1st; and that the rooms to which they moved in the building in which the arrest was made was rented to the pettiioner by Mr. Sue Key Line.
The woman and her husband, who is represented to be a prosperous merchant, appeared in court upon this hearing. They have the appearance of being above the average Chinaman.

This court has to do only with the determination of whether the petitioner was granting a fair hearing. The enforcement of the immigration laws is vested by Congress in the immigration department, whose findings are made final as to the facts in issue, provided a fair hearing is had. The rules of the department provide a procedure to be followed when an alien is arrested as being improperly in the country, and provide certain rights which should be accorded to the arrested party, among which are permission to secure advice and assistance of counsel to inspect the record, 2.
make a copy of the minutes of the hearing so far as they have been presented, and to offer evidence to meet any evidence presented. It is contended by the petitioner that she was not accorded such a hearing as is contemplated b y the Immigration Act; that she was denied the assistance of counsel; that she was not permitted to meet face to face the witnesses who testified against her; that she was denied the right of cross-examination of the witnesses; and that if the right of cross-examination had been accorded to her that every statement made by the policeman to which a wrongful conclusion has been attributed could have been elucidated in such a way from the statements of the witnesses themselves that would have shown conclusively that no improper relations of any kind had been sustained by the petitioner with the party in the room at the time of the arrest or at any time; and that they were in error as to the petitioner being in the room in question here prior to November 1, 1913. The petitioner and the party who was in the room with her swear that they were not in bed together. The Chinaman is stated to be a friend of the husband, and asked permission to sleep there for the night. He lay on a bed in one room and the petitioner lay on a sofa in another room. Both has their clothing on; and that there had been nothing improper between them.

A careful reading of the entire record convinces me that the petitioner was not accorded a fair hearing, and that the right of being represented by counsel and being afforded an opportunity of cross-examining the witnesses being denied her, deprived her of a right which the law accords, expecially under circumstances disclosed by the record in this case. This denial was prejudicial to her. It has been repeatedly held that the rules provided by the Immigration department contemplated a hearing at which the alien is allowed to be present and be confronted with witnesses and to have opportunity to cross-examine.
It is contended by the Government that Low Wah Suey v. Backus, 225 U.S. 460, 56 L. ed. 1165, is decisive of the question here raised. The court there said:

"From these rules it appears that, while provision is made for an examination in the absence of counsel, it is provided that a hearing shall be had at which the alien shall have full opportunity to show cause why he should not be deported, and that, at such stage of the proceedings as the person before whom apprixed that he may thereafter be represented by counsel, who shall be permitted to be present at the further conduct of the hearing."
Neither the petitioner nor her counsel were permitted to be present at any hearing or further hearing.

Judge Bean of the District of Oregonin the case of In re Chin You Gen, April 20, 1914, in a similar case based upon practically the same facts, the party being apprehended in the same raid, in discharging the petitioner, said:

"The doctine seems to be that no person can be deprived of his liberty and deported without an opportunity to show his right to remain and to present such evidence to the officers whose duty it is to pass upon this evidence.

Now, the warrant of deportation was issued by the authorities at Washington based upon the record as made up before the commissioner and it seems to me that under all the rules of procedure the petitioner in this case should have been allowed to have appeared either in person or by counsel, and that was on the 10th of November, but notwithstanding that the commissioiner took the testimony of the two material witnesses without the presence of the petitoner and denied the right of her counsel to be present at that hearing, and that, it seems to me, was a violation of the rules prescribed by the department."

A warrant of deportation was issued upon the record transmitted to the secretary of labor, in the preparation of which, or in the production of any of the evidence, the petitioner and her counsel were deprived of any participation, other than the submission of affidavits after the case of the Government has been closed.

I am forced to the conclusion that the action of the commissioner in taking the testimony of the material witnesses to substantiate the vital issue without the presence of the petitioner and in denying her the right of counsel to be present at that hearing to secure her the right of at least limited cross-examination, deprived 4.
the petitioner of a fair hearing such as is contemplated by the rules of the department.
The petitioner is entitled to a discharge.
2x No.
In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington
Filed in the U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington. May 1 1914 Frank L. Crosby, Clerk, By EML Deputy
